messages.subject: Re: Saotome tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Jim - Thanks for the info, as usual. I think I ll stick with Saotome. The work isn t really that different from the Saotome Tembo sukashi I have. The plates
messages.messageBody:
Jim -

Thanks for the info, as usual. I think I'll stick with
Saotome. The work isn't really that different from the
Saotome Tembo sukashi I have. The plates are really quite
similar and is the carving of the sukashi.

Rich

------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

The Japanese Sword Index
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm
------------------------------------------------------------

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Saotome tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Jim Just a feeling that it might be Hizen, nothing specific, probably because of the dragon. Alan ... From: Jim Gilbert  To:
messages.messageBody:
Jim
Just a feeling that it might be Hizen, nothing specific, probably because of
the dragon.
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Tuesday, July 22, 2003 7:14 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Saotome tsuba


: The combination of the sukashi and the dragon isn't adding up to any group
I can think of even if it is carved rather than etched. Not to say it's the
same type, but it reminds me a bit of the early type of tsuba with a dragon
carved down into a plain plate like the 3rd (last) guard here:
: http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/kamakura.htm
:
: Some sources call that kind of guard the beginning of the Kamakura-bori
style, others see it as an elaboration of the Tosho or Katchushi style.
Both may be correct, in that a one-off experiment could grow into a
"school." Or both may be wrong and the pieces were made by someone or a
group that had no actual connection with the makers of what look to us as
likely pre or post styles.
:
: Alan mentioned Hizen -- was that because of the style of the dragon?
:
: Jim
:
:
: Jim -
:
: Thanks. The dragon, etc could just be very, very low
: relief carving. I really can't tell. If it's not Saotome,
: what other schools might it be?
:
: Rich
:
:

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Saotome tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: The combination of the sukashi and the dragon isn t adding up to any group I can think of even if it is carved rather than etched.  Not to say it s the same
messages.messageBody:
The combination of the sukashi and the dragon isn't adding up to any group I can think of even if it is carved rather than etched. Not to say it's the same type, but it reminds me a bit of the early type of tsuba with a dragon carved down into a plain plate like the 3rd (last) guard here:
http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/kamakura.htm

Some sources call that kind of guard the beginning of the Kamakura-bori style, others see it as an elaboration of the Tosho or Katchushi style. Both may be correct, in that a one-off experiment could grow into a "school." Or both may be wrong and the pieces were made by someone or a group that had no actual connection with the makers of what look to us as likely pre or post styles.

Alan mentioned Hizen -- was that because of the style of the dragon?

Jim


Jim -

Thanks. The dragon, etc could just be very, very low
relief carving. I really can't tell. If it's not Saotome,
what other schools might it be?

Rich


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: Saotome tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: ... correct or not.  I don t think I ve seen any other acid etched pieces attributed to Saotome, but it could be.  It could also just be by someone with an
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...>
wrote:
> Rich,
> It does look like the one in Torigoye, whether the attribution is
correct or not. I don't think I've seen any other acid etched pieces
attributed to Saotome, but it could be. It could also just be by
someone with an independent idea. It looks like there is a tail down
in the 5-6 o'clock region.
>
> Jim

Jim -

Thanks. The dragon, etc could just be very, very low
relief carving. I really can't tell. If it's not Saotome,
what other schools might it be?

Rich
------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

The Japanese Sword Index
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm
------------------------------------------------------------

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Saotome tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, It does look like the one in Torigoye, whether the attribution is correct or not.  I don t think I ve seen any other acid etched pieces attributed to
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
It does look like the one in Torigoye, whether the attribution is correct or not. I don't think I've seen any other acid etched pieces attributed to Saotome, but it could be. It could also just be by someone with an independent idea. It looks like there is a tail down in the 5-6 o'clock region.

Jim



Sometimes things jump out and bite you after you've had them
awhile. I had this tsuba for a while and finally noticed
that it had a dragon in VERY low relief (almost Hoan style
relief etching). One the reverse is another dragon and a
flaming jewel. I first firgured katchushi, then maybe Umetada;
now I believe (?) it to be Saotome (Momoyama Era)
based on comparison with one in Tsuba Kanshoki (2nd Ed, the
one with the English captions), page 35 bottom pic.

http://gcclearn.gcc.vccs.edu/stein/saotome6.jpg

Any thoughts? Saotome or not? Certainly not a style I normally
have associated with Saotome.

Rich
------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

The Japanese Sword Index
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm
------------------------------------------------------------

messages.msgSnippet: Sometimes things jump out and bite you after you ve had them awhile. I had this tsuba for a while and finally noticed that it had a dragon in VERY low relief
messages.messageBody:
Sometimes things jump out and bite you after you've had them
awhile. I had this tsuba for a while and finally noticed
that it had a dragon in VERY low relief (almost Hoan style
relief etching). One the reverse is another dragon and a
flaming jewel. I first firgured katchushi, then maybe Umetada;
now I believe (?) it to be Saotome (Momoyama Era)
based on comparison with one in Tsuba Kanshoki (2nd Ed, the
one with the English captions), page 35 bottom pic.

http://gcclearn.gcc.vccs.edu/stein/saotome6.jpg

Any thoughts? Saotome or not? Certainly not a style I normally
have associated with Saotome.

Rich
